chief_complaint.definition: A variation or abnormality in the force of blood pushing against your artery walls. Your doctor is monitoring this because your blood pressure readings have not been consistently in a healthy range.
Treatment, usually with medication, designed to lower high blood pressure. Your doctor wants to reassess whether your current treatment plan is working well enough.
A sudden, temporary spike in blood pressure to dangerously high levels. You experienced one of these during the holiday period.
An abbreviation for blood pressure — the measurement of the force of blood against the walls of your arteries.
Short for 'millimeters of mercury,' this is the standard unit used to measure blood pressure.

history_of_present_illness.definition: A chronic condition where the pressure in your arteries is persistently higher than normal. This is the main condition your doctor is managing for you.
A doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating heart and blood vessel conditions. Dr. Nowak is the cardiologist who previously evaluated you.
Drugs prescribed specifically to lower high blood pressure. You were started on this type of medication a few months ago.
The force exerted by your blood against the walls of your arteries. It is measured as two numbers — systolic (top) over diastolic (bottom).
Millimeters of mercury — the standard unit of measurement for blood pressure readings.
The top number in a blood pressure reading, representing the pressure in your arteries when your heart beats and pumps blood out. Your reading of approximately 200 mmHg systolic was dangerously high.
The recorded measurements of the force of blood in your arteries, typically taken at home or in a doctor's office to track your condition over time.
Your morning home blood pressure range. The first number (130–137) is systolic pressure and the second (70–80) is diastolic pressure. These readings are in a near-normal range.
Your evening home blood pressure range. These readings are mildly elevated, especially the top number, which is above the ideal target for most people.
A feeling of being lightheaded, unsteady, or faint. It can sometimes be a symptom of very high or very low blood pressure. You reported not experiencing this.
Laboratory tests performed on a sample of your blood to check for various health markers such as cholesterol, blood sugar, and organ function.
A fatty substance in your blood. High cholesterol can increase the risk of heart disease and stroke. Your cholesterol values were not available at this visit.
The medical term for high blood pressure. Your mother has a history of this condition, which can run in families.
Medications used to treat high blood pressure. The fact that your siblings also take these suggests a family tendency toward high blood pressure.

review_of_systems.definition: Discomfort or pain felt in the chest area, which can be a sign of heart problems. You denied having this symptom.
The sensation of your heart beating unusually fast, hard, or irregularly. You denied experiencing this.
The measurement of the force of blood pushing against artery walls. You had a severely elevated episode during the holidays that has since resolved.
Millimeters of mercury, the standard unit for measuring blood pressure.
A sensation of feeling lightheaded or unsteady. You are not currently experiencing this.
The medical term for difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. You did not report this symptom.

physical_exam.definition: The force of blood against artery walls, measured during your visit today to assess how well your condition is being managed.
Your in-office blood pressure reading today. The top number (170, systolic) and bottom number (96, diastolic) are both elevated above normal targets.

A phenomenon where blood pressure readings are higher in a medical setting than at home, often due to anxiety or stress about seeing a doctor. Your doctor suspects this may explain your elevated in-office reading.
An ultrasound of the heart that uses sound waves to create images showing how well your heart is pumping and whether its structure is normal. Yours showed no significant problems.

An increase in the size of the left atrium, one of the upper chambers of the heart. This can sometimes result from long-standing high blood pressure. Your doctor confirmed this was not found in your case.
Short for electrocardiogram — a quick, painless test that records the electrical activity of your heart to detect rhythm problems or other abnormalities.
The normal, regular electrical pattern of your heartbeat, originating from the heart's natural pacemaker. This means your heart rhythm is healthy.
A test where you exercise (usually on a treadmill) while your heart is monitored to see how it performs under physical exertion. Your previous test was normal.

assessment.definition: A chronic condition of persistently elevated blood pressure in the arteries. Your doctor notes that your condition is currently well-controlled based on your home readings.
Your morning home blood pressure range. These values suggest your blood pressure is reasonably well-controlled in the morning.
The blood pressure reading taken at the doctor's office today, which was notably higher than your home measurements.
A condition where blood pressure is elevated in a clinical setting but normal at home. Your doctor suspects this may explain the difference between your home and office readings.
An ultrasound test of the heart. Yours was found to be unremarkable, meaning no abnormalities were detected.
Electrocardiogram — a test that records the electrical activity of the heart. Yours showed no abnormalities.
A test monitoring your heart during physical activity. Your prior test result was normal.
A dangerously high spike in blood pressure that can potentially damage organs. Your episode during the holidays appears to have been an isolated event.
A waxy, fat-like substance in the blood. Knowing your cholesterol levels is important because high cholesterol combined with high blood pressure increases heart disease risk.

plan.definition: A test where you wear a portable blood pressure cuff for a full day and night that automatically takes readings at regular intervals. This gives your doctor a complete picture of your blood pressure throughout your daily activities and sleep.
Abbreviation for ambulatory blood pressure monitoring — a 24-hour test that tracks your blood pressure outside of the doctor's office.
How well your blood pressure is being kept within a healthy range through medication and lifestyle measures.
A condition where blood pressure is elevated only in a medical setting. The ABPM test will help determine if this is what's happening with you.

Consistently high blood pressure that remains elevated throughout the day, not just in a doctor's office. The ABPM will help determine whether your high blood pressure is sustained or only occurs in clinical settings.
A medication that relaxes and widens blood vessels, making it easier for blood to flow and lowering blood pressure. You are currently taking 5 mg daily.
The dose of your Amlodipine medication — 5 milligrams taken once each day.
Regularly checking the levels of cholesterol in your blood through lab tests. This is important because high cholesterol combined with high blood pressure increases the risk of heart disease.
Laboratory tests performed on a blood sample to evaluate your overall health, including cholesterol and other important markers.
The regular measurement and recording of your blood pressure, which you do at home in the morning and evening to help track how well your treatment is working.
